schemas.description: The Southern Photometric Local Universe Survey (S-PLUS) -- Data Release 2

tables.description: Main object table containing photometry in g, i, r, u, z, f378, f395, f410, f430, f515, f660, and f861 bands.
Photometric redshifts table with values obtained via deep-learning using a Mixture Density Network.
Table of object classifications and their probabilities. The classification is done using a Random Forest algorithm trained with the 12 S-PLUS bands, FWHM_n, A, B, and KRON_RADIUS.

columns.description: Indication of the reference catalogue for calibration. 1: use of Stellar Locus. 2: SDSS (DR12). 4: SDSS (Ivezic7). 8: ATLAS RefCat2. 16: GALEX (DR6/7). 32: Skymapper (DR2).

HEALPIX index (Nside 256, Ring scheme => ~14 arcmin size)
HEALPIX index (Nside 4096, Ring scheme => ~52 arcsec size)
S-PLUS ID on this data release
Photometric redshift best single-point estimate, corresponding to the peak of the PDF.
Photometric redshift error obtained from the standard deviation of the 5 top contributing gaussians of the PDF
Number of peaks in the PDF
If n_peaks > 1, this is the photometric redshift corresponding to the second peak

Flag with the photo-z quality. 0 for samples that are inside the training sample parameter range, 1 for samples outside the training sample parameter range, but with r_aper_6 <= 21, 2 for objects outside the training r_aper_6 magnitude range (indicates extrapolation, should not be used)

Odds value calculated for the PDF as described in https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.06315. The Odds can be understood as a quality parameter where, the closer to 1, the more reliable (i.e, the less uncertain) the photo-z determination is
S-PLUS ID on this data release
Indicates the class of the source. 0 = QSO, 1 = star, 2 = galaxy.

Indicates by which model the classification was obtained. 0 = RF18, 1 = RF16. Where RF18 is the trained model from 12 S-PLUS ISO magnitudes (AB) + 2 WISE magnitudes (Vega) + 4 morphological features (FWHM_n, A, B, KRON_RADIUS) and RF16 is the trained model from 12 S-PLUS ISO magnitudes (AB) + 4 morphological features (FWHM_n, A, B, KRON_RADIUS).
Probability that the object is a galaxy, between 0 and 1.
Probability that the object is a QSO, between 0 and 1.
Probability that the object is a star, between 0 and 1.
